Issues.Title: fix(compiler): record correct end of expression
Issues.Body:

of an expression node was recorded as the start index of the next token,

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): type-checking of properties which map to multiple fields
Issues.Body:
It's possible to declare multiple inputs for a directive/component which all
map to the same property name. This is usually done in error, as only one of
any bindings to the property will "win".

In the template type-checker, an error was previously being raised as a
result of this ambiguity. Specifically, a type constructor was produced
which required a binding for each field, but only one of the fields had
a value via the binding. TypeScript would (rightfully) error on missing
values for the remaining fields. This ultimately was happening when the
code which generated the default values for "unset" inputs belonging to
directives or pipes used the final mapping from properties to fields as
a source for field names.

Instead, this commit uses the original list of fields to generate unset
input values, which correctly provides values for fields which shared a
property name but didn't receive the final binding.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): type-checking of properties which map to multiple fields" (#34482)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): add attributes and classes to host elements based on selector
Issues.Body:
In View Engine, host element of dynamically created component received attributes and classes extracted from component's selector. For example, if component selector is `[attr] .class`, the `attr` attribute and `.class` class will be add to host element. This commit adds similar logic to Ivy, to make sure this behavior is aligned with View Engine.

This PR resolves #34256.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): correctly associate output bound events with directives
Issues.Body:
Duplicate of #31938 targeting Version 9

---

Previously, bound events were incorrectly bound to directives with
inputs matching the bound event attribute. This fixes that so bound
events can only be bound to directives with matching outputs.

Adds tests for all kinds of directive matching on bound attributes.

Issues.Title: Unhelpful error message and error: TypeError: Cannot read property '1' of null
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package Ivy rendering with a directive, unclear error message ### Is this a regression? Yes, it appear to be, did not get any errors like this in Angular 7 ### Description I'm trying to get our companies application ported to Angular 9 from Angular 7. I've already made many fixes, and came across this one: ``` app.module.ts:177 [ERROR]: TypeError: Cannot read property '1' of null at providersResolver (di_setup.ts:46) at Object.definition.providersResolver (providers_feature.ts:48) at resolveDirectives (core.js:17) at elementStartFirstCreatePass (core.js:19023) at ɵɵelementStart (core.js:19023) at Module.ɵɵelement (core.js:19023) at NWTRecordingControlsNWTRecordingControlsDetailComponent_div_53_div_1_div_4_div_3_div_1_span_1_div_14_Template (nwtrecordingcontrolsnwtrecordingcontrols-detail.component.html:784) at executeTemplate (core.js:17) at renderView (core.js:17) at TemplateRef_.createEmbeddedView (core.js:17) ``` I'm sure there is a bug on our side, but wanted to report this as the error message is extremely unhelpful. The template code that is failing is: ```
``` Inside of this function: ``` export function providersResolver( def: DirectiveDef, providers: Provider[], viewProviders: Provider[]): void { const lView = getLView(); const tView: TView = lView[TVIEW]; if (tView.firstCreatePass) { const isComponent = isComponentDef(def); // The list of view providers is processed first, and the flags are updated resolveProvider(viewProviders, tView.data, tView.blueprint, isComponent, true); // Then, the list of providers is processed, and the flags are updated resolveProvider(providers, tView.data, tView.blueprint, isComponent, false); } } ``` The `lView` that is returned is null. Since the error is not clear, I am not yet sure of the cause. Once I find it, I'll leave a comment here. I have `angular-froala-wysiwg` imported locally (fork of https://github.com/froala/angular-froala-wysiwyg) since they don't have a release that works in Angular 9 yet (they latest release is still using the remove Angular Renderer). Package.json contents: ``` ... "angular-froala-wysiwyg": "file:../angular-froala-wysiwyg/dist", ... ``` ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Repo: https://github.com/arobinson/angular-bug-34478 Steps: 1. First build and run the app: ``` git clone git@github.com:arobinson/angular-bug-34478.git cd angular-bug-34478 npm i ng s -o ``` 2. Open the chrome developer tools console 3. Click on `Go to comp 2` 4. Notice the error (page loads blank) ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

app.module.ts:177 [ERROR]:  TypeError: Cannot read property '1' of null
    at providersResolver (di_setup.ts:46)
    at Object.definition.providersResolver (providers_feature.ts:48)
    at resolveDirectives (core.js:17)
    at elementStartFirstCreatePass (core.js:19023)
    at ɵɵelementStart (core.js:19023)
    at Module.ɵɵelement (core.js:19023)
    at NWTRecordingControlsNWTRecordingControlsDetailComponent_div_53_div_1_div_4_div_3_div_1_span_1_div_14_Template (nwtrecordingcontrolsnwtrecordingcontrols-detail.component.html:784)
    at executeTemplate (core.js:17)
    at renderView (core.js:17)
    at TemplateRef_.createEmbeddedView (core.js:17)

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): completions after "let x of |" in ngFor
Issues.Body:
This commit fixes a bug in which we do testing for completions. Subsequently, this exposes another bug in our implementation whereby suggestions are not provided in "ngFor" where there should have been. Currently, multiple test cases are grouped together in a single template. This requires the template to be somewhat complete so that test cases that depend on variables declared earlier would pass. Consider the following case: ```html template: `
Name: {{~{for-interp-person}person.~{for-interp-name}name}} Age: {{person.~{for-interp-age}age}}
`, ``` In order to test `~{for-interp-person}`, `people` has to be included after `~{for-people}`. This means the test case for `~{for-people}` is not reflective of the actual use case because the variable is already there! In real case, the expression would be incomplete, and our implementation failed to take that into account. This commit breaks such test into individual tests, and fix the bugs in the underlying implementation. ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [x] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Issues.Title: refactor(language-service): Append missing AttrAst to AstPath
Issues.Body:
When a HTML Ast containing an Attribute node is converted to a Template Ast,
the attribute node might get dropped from the Template Ast path.
This is because the AttrNode is not even in the Template Ast to begin with.
In this case, we manually fix the path by converting the Attribute node
to a AttrAst node and appending it to the path.

This allows the `ExpressionVisitor` to properly visit the leaf node in the
TemplateAst path and remove optional `attr` parameter passed to `ExpressionVisitor`.

Issues.Title: Ivy: components with OnPush cannot be marked as dirty in view lifecycle hooks
Issues.Body:
With View Engine, it was possible for developers to mark a component as dirty within the view init/checked lifecycle hooks using "markForCheck". This no longer seems to work in Ivy because the dirty-state of the component is _reset_ after the view lifecycle hooks have been executed. 

In View Engine, the order seems slightly different and a component dirty state is reset when it's children have been checked. The lifecycle hooks for the component execute when the parent view is checked. This means that a component can be marked from within the view lifecycle hooks since the dirty state is _not_ reset afterwards (unlike in Ivy)

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8eb05964639ea66e602f3c145728cb63ced706cd/packages/core/src/render3/instructions/shared.ts#L478 


**Reproduction**:

[View Engine Demo](https://ng-run.com/edit/Hq5Gbi5wOIsr6Bdymk1q?aot=false&open=app%2Fhello%2Fhello.component.ts)
[Ivy Demo](https://ng-run.com/edit/Hq5Gbi5wOIsr6Bdymk1q?aot=true&open=app%2Fhello%2Fhello.component.ts)

Also here is an acceptance test that shows the issue: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/30634

The test replicates a scenario where `MatCheckbox` calls `markForCheck` in the ngAfterViewInit lifecycle hook. Below is the sequence of actions View Engine performs in that test cae:

1.  Runs AfterViewInit hooks for children of: MatCheckbox (no children in this test scenario)
2.  Resets "ChecksEnabled"/Dirty-Flag for MatCheckbox instance
3.  Runs AfterViewInit hook for children of: MyTestComp (only children is the checkbox; so it runs the checkbox hook)
4.  AfterViewInit Hook of MatCheckbox marked the checkbox as dirty
5.  Runs AfterViewInit hooks for children of [ROOT]

-> After the change detection cycle, `MatCheckbox` is left as dirty. This is not the case in Ivy.

Reference ticket: FW-1354
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy: components with OnPush cannot be marked as dirty in view lifecycle hooks" (#34471)

Issues.Title: Ivy: Can't set default value for 'select' when options are generated dynamically through ngFor
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

Yes, it works in ViewEngine


### Description
While working with Ivy I noticed one incompatibility with ViewEngine.
Let's say we want to dynamically generate options for select and also assign default value

```
<select [value]="3">
  <option [value]="item" *ngFor="let item of [1,2,3]">{{ item }}</option>
</select>
```

ViewEngine will render 3 as selected value(https://ng-run.com/edit/rn9WBjLKXzXUEI8CSE3d) but in Ivy the first item will be selected(https://ng-run.com/edit/TXJC0ZhJTzrN8aYgUmtH?aot=true).

It's happening because the order of checking is different.In ViewEngine updateDirectives is called first(which triggers ngFor directive to render all options) and then updateRenderer is called which sets value to the select.
Ivy checks template from top to bottom so that it first sets default value and since there is no any options rendered it doesn't actually set it. And after that options are rendered.

ViewEngine behavior looks rational for me so I wonder if it's need to be fixed for Ivy. The workaround is using `selected` binding on `option` tag.

Please do note that similar React code(https://codesandbox.io/s/priceless-pare-lynml)

```
<select value={3}>
 {[1, 2, 3].map(item => <option value={item}>{item}</option>)}
</select>
```

works the same way as in ViewEngine


## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction

ViewEngine https://ng-run.com/edit/rn9WBjLKXzXUEI8CSE3d
Ivy 9.0.0-rc.6 https://ng-run.com/edit/TXJC0ZhJTzrN8aYgUmtH?aot=true
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy: Can't set default value for 'select' when options are generated dynamically through ngFor" (#34470)

Issues.Title: feat(router-link): Accept UrlTree as input
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 feat(router-link): Accept UrlTree as input

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/router

### Description
Currently [`[routerLink]`](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/router/src/directives/router_link.ts#L142) directive accepts either an array of commands or a string. Since angular uses `UrlTree` as a model to store urls, it'd be great to extend this directive so that in addition it accepts a `UrlTree`.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Let `[routerLink]` input accept `commands: any[]|string|UrlTree`.


### Describe alternatives you've considered

* A different directive for this purpose. But having already a directive for that it'd be great to just extend the API.
* A pipe that converts a `UrlTree` into a string. The problem is that the params that a `UrlTree` might include should be extracted and put in their respective inputs. So that doesn't play nicely with all the features `UrlTree` have.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(router-link): Accept UrlTree as input" (#34468)

Issues.Title: feat(service-worker): improve default `SwRegistrationStrategy`
Issues.Body:
**The problem**

In order to avoid negatively affecting the initial page-load time, `@angular/service` worker will (by default) wait for the [app to stabilize][1], before registering the SW  script. This can lead to a situation where the SW will never be registered when there is a long-running task (such as an interval or recurring timeout), which can often be started by a 3rd-party dependency (without the developer realizing). Related issues: #20970, #34461

This can easily be missed by the developer and there is no other indication other than the SW is not in effect. This is particularly hard to detect, because the SW is typically not used during development and on production builds a previous SW instance might be in effect.

##
**Possible solutions**

Since 4cfba5807, it is possible to overwrite this default behavior by [providing a different `SwRegistrationStrategy`][2]. Things we could do to remedy the situation (non-exhaustive list; up for discussion):

- Change the default strategy to a custom one that wait for the app to stabilize, but registers anyway after X seconds (not matter whether stabilized or not).

- Keep the current behavior, but print a warning after X seconds that the app has not stabilized yet and the SW has not been registered. (This won't change the current behavior, but will make it easier for developers to identify the problem.)

[1]: https://angular.io/api/core/ApplicationRef#is-stable-examples
[2]: https://angular.io/api/service-worker/SwRegistrationOptions#registrationStrategy
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(service-worker): improve default `SwRegistrationStrategy`" (#34464)

Issues.Title: Loadchildren (dynamic imports) in routing not working when 'enableIvy' is set to true in tsconfig.app.json
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 BUG REPORT ### Description When I use loadChildren inside a children array the child modules are not loaded. This happens only when enableIvy is set to true. Works fine if enableIvy is set to false. Also aot is set to true in angular.json. Also there is no error shown. Only the parent component is loaded (PageComponent) in this case. 

const PAGE_ROUTES: Routes = [
  {
    path: ' ',
    component: PageComponent,
    children: [
      {
        path: 'child1',
        loadChildren: () => import('../../../child1/child1.module').then(m => m.child1Module)
      },
      {
        path: 'child2',
        loadChildren: () => import('../../../child2/child2.module').then(m => m.child2Module)
      }
    ]
  }
];
If the loadChildren modules are specified directly (shown below) everything works fine even when ivy is enabled. But I can't do that in the above shown case as I have to display the modules inside the parent based on the route. 
 

  { path: '', loadChildren: () => import('./shared/modules/page/page.module').then(m => m.PageModule) },

Issues.Title: Angular ng object is missing in production bundles in developer tools console
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8 ### Description In angular version 8 I had access to `window.ng` object in chrome developer tools console either in development build and in production build. Today I realized that with the 9.0.0-rc.x version (9.0.0-rc.5) I'm not able to access the `ng` object if the app is compiled for production. **PRODUCTION:** ![image](https://i.stack.imgur.com/li4Dk.gif) **DEVELOPMENT:** ![image](https://i.stack.imgur.com/pXJZZ.gif) ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Just use cli to generate a brand new project, upgrade it to the latest rc version and compile it to production. In the browser console, try to access `ng` object. ## 🔥 Exception or Error No exceptions are thrown. ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:**

# 🐞 bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
The issue is caused by package @angular/forms. maybe?


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
 Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was:  8.2.14


### Description

<!-- ✍️--> A clear and concise description of the problem...

Our app is a dynamically generated form, with custom inputs using the `ControlValueAccessor` interface in order to bind those custom input changes to the main form.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3651787/71014994-d9e9a880-20c0-11ea-9803-33a4d4c76a0e.png)

After some testing I found something interesting, if I remove the following snippet `[required]="kapInput.required"` the error is gone. I also tried harcoding the required property to _true_ or _false_ but the error was still present. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3651787/71015147-21703480-20c1-11ea-8833-7b809e268624.png)

So I'm not sure if this is related to the forms package (due to the validations), a _False-positive_ error check due that the validation is working, or anything related to IVY.


## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction
<!--
Please create and share minimal reproduction of the issue starting with this template: https://stackblitz.com/fork/angular-issue-repro2
-->

I managed to create repo, reproducing the error. Here's the link
_9-update_ branch
https://github.com/camilogiraldo/dynamic-forms/tree/9-update

Issues.Title: --aot : "Unexpected Value in imported module. Please add a @NgModule annotation"
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: v 5.2.11 ### Description Application serves well when --aot is not enabled. But on enabling aot, the compiler seems to throw an error requesting to add the @NgModule annotation. The issue seems to point out to one of the external modules imported. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Have Created a GitHub repository for minimal reproduction of the issue. 1. Clone the repository from [https://github.com/AntonyJos/angularIssue.git](https://github.com/AntonyJos/angularIssue.git) 2. Run `npm install` 3. Execute `ng serve`. Navigate to http://localhost:4200/. Everything works fine. 4. Execute `ng serve --aot`. 5. Application Fails to compile Expecting the application to be compiled successfully as was the case with JIT ## 🔥 Exception or Error 



ERROR in : Unexpected value 'Module name in D:/angularIssue/node_modules/....d.ts' imported by the module 'AppModule in D:/angularIssue/src/app/app.module.ts'. Please add a @NgModule annotation.

Issues.Title: Angular 9 wepack server.ts fails due to custom paths
Issues.Body:
I just trying out the latest version on Angular 9 and both of the following run without issue
ng build client --prod
ng run client:server:production

but when i run webpack on my server.ts I get a load of errors relating to imports using custom paths from my tsconfig i.e

```
 "paths": {
      "@env/*": ["projects/environments/*"]
    }
```

```
ERROR in ./projects/client/src/app/app.module.ts
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve '@env/environment' in '/projects/client/src/app'
 @ ./projects/client/src/app/app.module.ts 9:0-47 43:24-35 48:36-47 56:25-36 60:33-44 69:29-40
 @ ./projects/client/src/app/app.server.module.ts
 @ ./projects/client/src/main.server.ts
 @ ./projects/client/server.ts
```
Any ideas as to how I can resolve this?

Issues.Title: ng update --next leads to wrong tsconfig.lib.prod.json path
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? nope, this is related to angular 9 migration ### Description When upgrading a **library** to angular 9, ie `ng update @angular/cli @angular/core --next`, `angular.json` is updated to reference `tsconfig.lib.prod.json`. The path is wrong, as it's missing a leading dot (`.`) ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction - clone https://github.com/mpalourdio/ng-http-loader - run `ng update @angular/cli @angular/core --next` - yarn build --prod ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/tsconfig.lib.prod.json'
## 🌍 Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.6
Node: 12.13.0
OS: linux x64

Angular: 9.0.0-rc.6
... cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, language-service
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.900.0-rc.6
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.900.0-rc.6
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.900.0-rc.6
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer    0.900.0-rc.6
@angular-devkit/build-webpack      0.900.0-rc.6
@angular-devkit/core               9.0.0-rc.6
@angular-devkit/schematics         9.0.0-rc.6
@ngtools/webpack                   9.0.0-rc.6
@schematics/angular                9.0.0-rc.6
@schematics/update                 0.900.0-rc.6
ng-packagr                         9.0.0-rc.3
rxjs                               6.5.3
typescript                         3.6.4
webpack                            4.41.2
**Anything else relevant?** Changing `/tsconfig.lib.prod.json` to `./tsconfig.lib.prod.json` fixes the issue. Generated configuration ```json "architect": { "build": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr:build", "options": { "tsConfig": "./tsconfig.lib.json", "project": "./ng-package.json" }, "configurations": { "production": { "tsConfig": "/tsconfig.lib.prod.json" } } }, } ```

Issues.Title: ng build consumes all memory & swap
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Unknown ### Description From time to time (maybe one in 8-10 times) the build seems to run away consuming memory infinitely and crashing my machine if I don't catch it and kill it quick enough. Below is a screen shot of system monitor for one such event (where I did catch it in time) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3340874/70866051-aed14e80-1f32-11ea-96ef-9a9bb6f8e760.png) The build I am running is a slightly modified version of the output from `ng new` ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction 1. Open System Monitor, to resources page, and be ready to kill what you are about to start. 1. clone git@github.com:nsoft/ns-login.git 1. checkout revision 198c3f677d77652f59c6e7b08e4ef1dcf273436d 1. cd into the /admin directory 1. run `ng build` several times (or `./gradlew build` which in turn runs ng build) I have seen this occur with `ng build` run on the command line, run via gradle, or run via intellij invoking gradle when deploying to tomcat. About 50% of the time when this happens the build fails after locking up the computer for a couple minutes. I suspect this the OS killing it (but haven't tried to verify. This survival seems more likely if the machine was not running low on memory to start with. ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

No Error, just an unresponsive computer that remains unresponsive >30 min, 
with all memory and swap consumed.
## 🌍 Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.3.20
Node: 11.8.0
OS: linux x64
Angular: 
... 

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.803.20
@angular-devkit/core         8.3.20
@angular-devkit/schematics   8.3.20
@schematics/angular          8.3.20
@schematics/update           0.803.20
rxjs                         6.4.0
**Anything else relevant?** No browser involved I am developing on Ubuntu 18.0.4. The above specified revision represents a very slightly modified version of the output from `ng new` I am quite new to Angular, and so My normal assumption would be that I've messed something up, and I'd hesitate to file a report, but _intermittent_ run-away memory like this has to be a bug, even if it resulted from some thing I did... I searched, but the bugs I find talk about out of memory errors, and that's not my case. Another interesting bit is that the process list in System Monitor will NOT show any process consuming a corresponding hunk of memory, so you can't find and kill it that way.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng build consumes all memory & swap" (#16454)

Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

See:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-emika8

Steps to reproduce:
1. Make a component that uses MAT_CHECKBOX_CLICK_ACTION noop to disable default checkbox handling, and an explicit click handler to toggle state.
2. Open in Chrome on Android, with TalkBack enabled.
3. Try to toggle the checkbox by double-tapping (normal selection gesture for TalkBack).

Issues.Title: Avoid adding multiple tooltip body click listeners

Tooltip defines a body click listener: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/b56bcadaeaf2420c7a0e3dac429f47e67a058bee/src/material/tooltip/tooltip.ts#L627

We probably don't want one of these per tooltip, and we also probably want to only register it when a tooltip is actually open. The way it is now, I'm wondering if it causes a change detection every time anyone clicks anywhere.

Issues.Body:

Steps to reproduce:
1. Define a mat-table with 2 sticky columns on the left 
2. Use the horizontal scrollbar
3. Position of the second column is not correctly computed
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

Two sticky columns, correctly positioned and not moving when using the horizontal scrollbar.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

1. Sometimes, the second sticky column is actually moving when using the horizontal scrollbar (see the 3rd example on my stackblitz)

#### Environment

- Browser(s): Firefox 71.0, Chromium 75.0.3770.142

Issues.Title: mat form field underline not animating correctly
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-une28f

Steps to reproduce:
1. Insert a form field with type="standard" or type="fill"
2. Hover over the form field with your mouse
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The .mat-form-field-underline element is supposed to animate smoothly, going from semi-transparent to opaque, without instantaneous vertical jumps.

#### Actual Behavior

When hovering over the form element, the mat-form-field-underline element animates smoothly, but appears ~ 2 px below the original underline. Once the animation is finished, the underline jumps up to where the original underline was.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.3.20
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Google Chrome 79.0.3945.79, Edge 44.18362.449.0
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

#### Additional information 
If I disable the CSS attribute "transform: scaleY(1.0001)" from the .mat-form-field-underline class, the underline animates correctly on Chrome. This workaround does not work on Edge.

This bug does also not appear every time you visit a page with the aforementioned form fields, but reloading the page will usually trigger the error.

Provided is a video recording documenting the bug in the provided StackBlitz environment.
https://gyazo.com/3dfaa24254ae82c3d7002e6e002f7507
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat form field underline not animating correctly" (#17998)

Issues.Title: fix(sidenav): move focus into sidenav in side mode if autoFocus enabled explicitly
Issues.Body: This PR is the result of the discussions in #17967. Currently we don't move focus into the sidenav if it's in `side` mode, because we don't know the context that the component is used in, however in some cases it makes sense to move focus anyway. These changes make it so that if the consumer explicitly opted into `autoFocus`, we always move focus into the sidenav, no matter what mode it's in.

Issues.Body:
We don't want to build the runfile tree's for the executable
devserver targets. In the CI, we are only interested in building
the actual "ng_module" target to ensure the dev-app/e2e-app are
not broken. Building the devserver runfiles is just wasteful.

I looked for more targets that we could exclude, but didn't find any..

Issues.Title: angular component vs ReactDOM.render
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal: PS:I have a react component, that have a button and on clicking, a modal popup shows. I compile the react build and use the js and cs files in a chrome extension. My chrome extension put a div with class awvComponent on multiple places in a web app and my react component rendered against each element that have the class. Following code is doing this perfectly. ``` class App extends React.Component { render() { return(
Modal COde here
); } } const elements = document.getElementsByClassName('awvComponent'); for(var i=0; i< elements.length; i++ ){ ReactDOM.render(, elements[i]); } export default App; ``` Now I want to have the same implementation in angular. I have created the same functionality in angular 8. Where I have a component that have button and on clicking button a modal appears. And its selector is awv-component. When I put the selector in app.component.html multiple times my awv-component render multiple times in UI, means multiple button created and each have its own modal. I have to use this functionality in my chrome extension. I created the production build and put js and css code in my extension. My chrome extension injected some tags in web application. And this time angular component only created for first tag and not for the other tags. So is that is achievable in angular 8, to create a angular component and then render it out side the angular app, using the selector, on multiple places of html page ``` Angular Component Reuse
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "angular component vs ReactDOM.render" (#17982)

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-slide-toggle): initial checked and disabled state not reflected visually
Issues.Body:
The initial `checked` and `disabled` state of the slide-toggle
is not reflected visually. This is because we sync the disabled
and checked state after the foundation has been created in the
`ngAfterViewInit` lifecycle hook.

The foundation then tries to set the classes on the MDC switch
element using the adapter. The adapter just updates an object
literal that will be passed through `[ngClass]` and relies on
Angular to refresh the view.

This won't work in Ivy because marking a component as dirty
from within the `ngAfterViewInit` lifecycle hook is a noop at the time
of writing. See: FW-1354.

Just using the native element (like we do in other MDC components)
solves this problem and also avoids unnecessary change detections.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental/mdc-slide-toggle): initial checked and disabled state not reflected visually" (#17991)

Issues.Title: 2 mat-autocomplete boxes overlapping. second box unclickable
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
Steps to reproduce:
1. Place 2 mat-autocomplete elements underneath each other
2. Click the bottom mat-autocomplete and try to select an item
3. Item is not clickable and selects the autocomplete above.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior
Both autocomplete boxes should work independently.


#### Actual Behavior
The autocomplete box from the first element blocks the click function on the second box.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1346522/70996973-44581400-20d4-11ea-8058-9c166290a74b.png)

This visualisation shows the first box overlapping the second. Normaly you would not see this box but the "invisable" box will still interfere with the second box. So only Accum and Adalady are clickable.


#### Environment

- Angular: 7.2.15 
- Ionic 4.9.1
- CDK/Material: 7.3.7
- Browser(s): Chrome/firefox (mobile and web)
- Operating System: Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "2 mat-autocomplete boxes overlapping. second box unclickable" (#17987)

Issues.Title: feat(a11y): allow to queue announcements in LiveAnnouncer
Issues.Body:
Standard LiveAnnouncer operates with a single aria-live element, which means that if several
announcements happen at the same time, only the latest one is actually announced. This change adds
`useQueue` configuration to LiveAnnouncerDefaultOptions. When it's set to `true` LiveAnnouncer
creates a separate aria-live element for each of the announcements and places all messages in
the queue, so they are announced one by one.

Fixes #17852
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(a11y): allow to queue announcements in LiveAnnouncer" (#17986)

Issues.Title: Template errors after updating to v9
Issues.Body:
<!--------

The Angular team can't provide general troubleshooting help. However, the extended community of
users can provide more help: 

StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/angular-material2
Gitter: https://gitter.im/angular/material2
Google Groups: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/angular-material2

Issues should capture only bug reports and feature requests. However, we understand that 
it is not always clear whether an issue is caused by a bug or incorrect usage of a feature/component.

Most support requests will be automatically closed. If the answer is quickly obvious, though, we 
might be able to provide a brief answer.

-------->

After doing an ng update from 8.2 to 9 i get all sorts of errors in the templates that previously did not show. Some of them:

`No directive found with exportAs 'matMenu'.` for a template that worked just fine 
```
  <mat-menu #actionsMenu="matMenu">
        <button mat-menu-item>More Actions Here</button>
      </mat-menu>
```

`'mat-sidenav' is not a known element:`
```
  <mat-sidenav #sidenav [opened]="sidenavOpen" [mode]="sidenavOpen ? 'side' : 'over'"
                         position="end"
            style="width: 280px;">
```

There's just too many of them to demonstrate. As mentioned above, everything used to work fine in 8.2 and my imports come from a shared module like so
```
import { MatSelectModule } from '@angular/material/select';
import { MatSidenavModule } from '@angular/material/sidenav';
import { MatMenuModule } from '@angular/material/menu';
```
  
#### Environment


Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.6
Node: 12.4.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.0.0-rc.6
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Issues.Title: build: update scss-bundle to avoid node-sass dependency
Issues.Body:
The `scss-bundle` package has a dependency on `node-sass` in the older
versions. This makes our tooling reliant on native bindings, and requires
additionally work in framework where we integrate our tooling into a different
environment setup (e.g. different node version).

Regardless of that though, it's generally better not relying on node-sass
or native bindings since we use `sass` (not node-sass) for building with Bazel.

**Note**: we still have an unused dependency on `node-sass` through `gulp-sass`.. but that will be gone eventually.. and at the moment we don't use `node-sass` at all (which is good)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: update scss-bundle to avoid node-sass dependency" (#17978)

Issues.Title: build: enable strict attribute type checking
Issues.Body:
When we initially enabled strict template type checking in the
components repository, we temporarily disabled the strict attribute
type checking due to an issue with `NgModel` and the disabled input.

`NgModel` seems to behave as expected and the issue we are facing for
some elements where `NgModel#disabled` is incompatible with the
disabled input of Angular Material components (where string is allowed)
is correctly reported by ngtsc.

We can satisfy both input signatures and actually enable the flag to
catch attribute typing/coercion issues which are actually affecting
components we ship.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: enable strict attribute type checking" (#17977)

Issues.Title: fix(stepper): last step not being marked as interacted
Issues.Body:
Fixes the last step in the stepper never being marked as `interacted`. Also fixes some weird logic where we were changing the step state inside `_anyControlsInvalidOrPending` which is a getter method.

Fixes #17974.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(stepper): last step not being marked as interacted" (#17976)
